bibl.title: Lay Students and the Making of Written Vernacular Narrative: an Inventory of Tun-huang Manuscripts

head.p: Victor Mair's catologue describing five-hundred and ninety-nineDunhuangmanuscripts and highlighting the importance of these early Chinese narrative texts in relation to oral performance. Taken fromChinoperl Papers, No. 10 (1981), pp. 5–96.

Abbreviations used in this inventory: PK (Peking ms #, see appendix two), S (Steinms #), P (Pelliotms #), F (Flug ms #), D (Dun’-khuanskogo Fonda ms #), T (Tun-huang pien-wen chi), r˚ (recto), v˚ (verso).R° is determined by which side of the ms was originally used for writing, v° by the side subsequently used. In the inventory, that side appears first which is more pertinent to the present subject of research.ms[s] (manuscript[s]).
Symbols: → “emend to; {x} “x is Mair's reconstruction/the translation of Mair's reconstruction”; ? “I am not certain”; = “is a variant orthography for”; [ ] ”understood” or “needs to be inserted”; // “end of line”.
Caution: Many of the translations in this inventory are highly tentative and are intended merely to serve as the basis for further discussion and research by specialists.

This catalogue is divided into the following sections:
(i) Paris (1–235)
(ii) London (236–437)
(iii) St Petersburg (437–551) N.B.: Except where noted, the Tun-huang mss in Leningrad consist of fragments that have not been fully identified with regard to subject matter, form, and genre.
(iv) China (552–597) N.B.: Items 594–597 are dispersed mss in China. Information taken from pp. 314–356 of Tun-huang i-shu tsung-mu so-yin. Since none of these mss is available for examination, I have been unable to verify any of the information given here.
(v) Taiwan (598 only)
(vi) Addendum (599 only)

note.p: “Classified Notes on theYogācāryabhūmi-śāstra”瑜伽師地論分門記as related by thebhadantaand Tripitaka Dharma Master,Fa-ch’eng大德三藏法師法成. Written in a very hurried hand. Owned by thesramaṇasT’an-hsün談迅andFu-hui福慧. After their names, which appear at the head of each chapter, comes the remark“heard”聽or“while listening along”隨聽or“note made while listening along”隨聽記. Their names also occur in alternation on v° where the seams of separate sheets of paper are joined. Many corrections, additions, and erasures, both in red and in black ink. Punctuation and highlighting in red. Rather thick, soft, ordinary beige paper (except). Other, mostly Zen, texts are copied on v° of, including a “Eulogy of theDiamond Sūtra,” one fascicle金剛經讚一卷 (head title),金剛讚一卷 (end title). See also the entry for.
Various hymns and eulogies, one addressed toChang I-ch’ao張義潮. Amongst them a “Seat-Settling Text”押座文(head title). T842. Has identifyingya-tso-wenformula. Rapid, fairly good hand.
Esoteric text. Drab paper of good quality; good hand, well spaced. Orange highlighting and punctuation; additions and corrections.

Pao-ta保達, identified as a member of the“company of disciples”徒衆, signs his name to a report on the disbursements and receipts of thePure Land Monastery淨土寺. Datedthe first month of 925. May be the same person as the quondam owner of. The signature appears to be that of someone who is barely literate. Based on the scanty information that is available,Pao-ta— like the copyist of,Hsüeh An-chün— must have been a layman who was deeply involved in the affairs of the monastery and who was actively engaged in learning about Buddhism.

Much used, ordinary coarse, fibrous, beige paper. Fairly good hand; a few changes and corrections; some highlighting in red. Colophon (same hand):“Copied by the student,Hsüe An-chün, onthe seventeenth day of the fifth month of the year 924. Especially retained for recitation by the faithful disciple,Li Chi-shun. The copyist of this scroll is the same person as the copyist of.

First part of a commentary on theVimalakīrti-sūtraoriginating fromShensi. Colophon (same hand):“Onthe first day of the first month of thejen-ch’enyear (932?), thebhadantaand recipient of the purple, the venerableTs’aofromwest of the Yellow Riverwho is in charge ofsaṇghaadministration for the capital and who has been to the royal city to present discussions before the emperor, went to theK’ai-yüan Monasteryto lecture on theVimalakīrti-sūtraas part of the services to theGod of the City Wallfor averting calamity. “Vimalakīrti[-sūtra]Seat-Settling Text”維摩押座文(head title). Used in collation of T829–823. Has identifyingya-tso-wenformula and the refrain “Buddhaputra”佛子. Followed immediately by heptasyllabic verses on theVimalakīrti-sūtra(lack title). T589–591. There is a long, clear break after T590.4 in which are written, upside-down, notes on theVimalakīrti-sūtra(these occur, at intervals, across v° in a fairly good, rapid hand). The section following is labeled“Chapter onupāya”方便品. Lacks indentifying formula forchiang-ching-wen. Then a sūtra lecture text for part of theAmitābha-sūtra. “Bitter Lament of Hell”地獄苦吟(head title). Main text for the collation of T482–486. Has identifying formula forchiang-ching-wen. Many evidences of oral peformamce:“What follows is spoken”此下白道.“Continuing the lecture”講下.“Sing it clearly in theshangmode”清涼商調唱將來.“What follows is the singing of thesūtra”此下唱經, etc. Also has the refrain “Buddhaputra”佛子. The three main texts on v° are in mediocre hands. Punctuation, additions, corrections, erasures.

msItem.title: Seat-Settling Text for ‘Defeat of the Transformations of Demons’
降魔變押座文

note.p: “Seat-Settling Text for ‘Defeat of the Transformations of Demons’”降魔變押座文(head title). “Destruction of the Transformations of Demons,” one scroll破魔變一卷 (end title). Main text for collation of T344–355. From the beginning to T345.7 constitutes aya-tso-wenand it may be so identified by the final sūtra title quotation formula. No sūtra title, however, is forthcoming. Instead, there is a prose bridge consisting of topical matters, including praise for the local governor,Chang I-ch’ao(referred to as僕射). The story of the “Destruction of the Transformations of Demons” proper begins on T346.1. Its typical identifying pre-verse formula is“At that time, what words did he speak?”當尔之時道何言語or its variations and abbreviations (“And so forth and so on.”“The Buddha said.”“The woman said.”云〻,仏道,女道). Although the author, who refers to himself (小僧,某乙) several times, does not quote and explain scripture as does the author of a typical sūtra lecture text, he may have considered this achiang-ching-wennonetheless because in line T355.8 he refers to what he has been doing as講經. Colophon (same hand):“Inscription of copying after blowing on my brush which had become frozen onthe tenth day of the eleventh month of the year 944.”天福九年甲辰祀黃鐘之月蓂生十葉冷凝呵笔而寫記. Additional colophon (same hand but smaller because squeezed in later):“Copied by the Buddhistvinaya śramaṇa,Yüan-jung, who resides in thePure Land Monastery.”居淨土寺釋門法律沙門願榮寫. In spite of the date944in the colophon, which falls during the Later Chin 後晉, the text must originally have been composed sometime between the years907and923, viz. the Later Liang 後梁 which is referred to in T354.13. The copyist seems to have been working from another fixed, written (or, less likely, oral) text. At line 25 of the ms (before T346.1), lines 345.13b–16 are missing from the text. In reading over what had been written, the copyist noticed their absence and inserted a mark (＞) where they should have been. He then proceeded to write themafterthe final title. Followed immediately in same hand by praise of the Emperor (T856.12.10–856.13) and then by a “Nidānaon Four Animals”四獸因緣(head title). Note which occurs in the middle of the text and separates the introductory prose section from the verse:“Hymn on the Kindnesses of the Four Animals Composed by the T’ang monk, ‘SaṇghaSupervisor.’”唐僧統和尚讚述四獸恩義頌. T855–856. Finally, there is a declaration of special rights enjoyed by temples and monasteries (incomplete, also in the same hand). Coarse, fibrous, light beige paper of mediocre quality; a bit thick; stains. Good hand, lightly cursive; a few additions and corrections.

“MaudgalyāyanaNidāna”目連緣起(head title). “NidānaofMahāmaudgalyāyana”大目連緣起(title, written very large at torn edge of scroll). T701–712. Colophon (same hand): “Inscription ofChieh-tao’s true copy”界道真本記. Ordinary, soft, rather thick, light drab paper. Fairly rapid, slightly better than middling hand; a few additions and corrections.

note.p: Patch of paper pasted on this ms mentions a “Seat-Settling Text ofthe Eighth Day of the Second Month”二月八日押座文(title only).

Letter of salutation from the head of a Buddhist monastery (on separate sheet of paper attached to front of pre-existent scroll). Sūtra lecture text on theVimalakīrti-sūtra(lacks title). T592–618. Good, light drab paper. Mediocre hand; few additions, corrections; red and black highlighting. Colophon (same hand):“Onthe ninth day of the eight month in 947at theZen Temple of Serene Truthinwestern Szechwan, I finished writing out this copy of the twentieth scroll just as it became dark. I don’t know how I can get back to my village.”廣政十年八月九日在西川靜真禪院寫此第廿卷文書恰遇[#8](=抵)黑書了 不知如何得到鄉地去. Second colophon (in a larger, cruder hand; if by the same hand as the first colophon [several key characters do match於,年, etc.], it was certainly written at a different time):“I am now forty-eight years old and am holding a lecture at theYingming Templein the prefecture. It is exceedingly hot.”年至四十八歲於州中[#9](=應, well within the range of Tun-huang orthographical variants for this character, even as attested elsewhere in this very ms)明寺開講極是溫熱. Has identifyingchiang-ching-wenformula.

Semivernacular promistetric narrative aboutPrince Siddhārtha’s attainment of the way (lacks title; beginning and ending missing). msItem.title: Sūtra lecture text on the Lotus Sūtra

note.p: Sūtra lecture text on theLotus Sūtra(lacks title). T488-500. Fairly good, drab paper. Fairly good hand. Very few corrections and additions. Had identifyingchiang-ching-wenformula.

A series of exhortations by a preacher to his congregation, largely heptasyllabic verse, to take to heart the teachings of the sūtras (especially theInconstancy Sūtra无常經) and to come often to the“lecture courtyard”講院to hear him elucidate them. T656–670. Slightly better than average hand. Lackschiang-ching-wenidentifying formula.

msItem.title: Transformation Text on Mahāmaudgalyāyana Searching for his Mother in the Netherworld
大目乾連冥間救母變文

note.p: “Transformation Text onMahāmaudgalyāyanaSearching for his Mother in the Netherworld,” one scroll大目乾連冥間救母變文一卷 (head title). “Transformation Text onMahāmaudgalyāyana,” one scroll大目犍連變文一卷 (title at end). Abbreviated version used in collation of T714–744. Notation at beginning just below title:“After two or three lines of eachgāthā, we abridge with the words ‘and so on and so forth.’”其偈子每[#10]三兩句後云云是. Has indentifying formula forpien-wen. Light beige paper, coarse and thick. Fairly rapid hand but neatly written in ruled columns; few additions, no erasures or corrections. The copyist seems to have been working from a well-established written text relatively far removed from its oral predecessor. Once he forgets the importance vestige of oral performance,“the place where…”(at T725.9) and has to add it later. He nearly omits it again at T737.3.

Semivernacular prosimetric narrative aboutNanda難阤leaving home to become a monk (lacks title). T395–403. Fragment torn off at beginning and unfinished at end. Beginning of a Buddhist anecdote. Careless hand.

The T editors are probably incorrect in indicating the last line (“the transformation of ugliness that was told above”上來所說醜變), which refers back to 798.2, to be some sort of title. The line in question occurs at the end of a verse passage. After it, the text breaks off abruptly at the end of a column because the sheet of paper ends. Subsequent sheets may have become detached. The characters in this line are the same size, shape, and placement as those in the rest of the text. The verse passages of this text are laid out in seven-character groups. The last line appears to be a deficient heptasyllabic line and could be completed with the addition of 媚 “alluring” (cf. 798.4). Illustrated transformation tableau (pien-hsiang變相) scroll for use in transformation (pien變) storytelling, i.e. storytelling with pictures. Unique and inestimably precious. Scenes on r° correspond exactly to those in the “Transformation Text on the Subjugation of Demons”降魔變文(T361–389), although the entire narrative does not survive on the present scroll. On v° of each scene are the verse portions (written in a mediocre hand with mistakes and corrections) of the transformation text which describe the episode depicted on r°. There are no prose passages on this scroll. Ordinary beige paper. The colored drawings exhibit a fairly high degree of technical skill and imagination. Especially to be noted is the artist’s deliberate employment of what I call the “continuous narrative” technique.

It is possible that this enigmatic notation refers to the means whereby the quondam owner(s) of this scroll came into possession of it.Yüan-ch’angmany be one of the inscribers of.Wen-pinmay be the official scribe who wrote(datedthe eight month of 970). The latter ms is a letter from theChief Escort of the Military Governor and Overseer of CopyistsMa Wen-pin節度押衙知司書手馬文斌(so titled at head; cf.v°). The letter and accompanying poem offer support for my surmise above (thatWen-pinwas involved in the procurement of the illustrated transformation tableau scroll for storytelling now known as). Both the letter and the poem clearly displayWen-pin’s intense attraction for vivid, dynamic Buddhist art:
Chief Escort of the Military Governor and Overseer of Copyists,Ma Wen-pin
I, the aforementionedWen-pin, was accompanying your Honor while you stopped in this village when I saw a bejewelled elephant on a colourful wall-painting. Although I am not talented, I immediately composed a short poem made up of heptasyllabic verse with four rhymed couplets. I hereby respectfully present it to you with this letter, begging that you will favor it with you kind consideration when you read it. Respectfully I record the poem on this letter and present it to you in the form of previous respectful communications.
Letter of the Chief Escort of the Military Governor and Overseer of Copyists,Ma Wen-pin, on the…th day of the eighth month of the year 970.
The rare, bejewelled elephant is a king among beasts,
Throughout the world, there is no match for this fierce valor and heroic heart;
His four legs are planted as jade pillars,
His pair of tusks are sharp as the tip of a steel sword.
As he stands surveying the steep crags, he becomes a mountain,
When he moves, his swaying form terrifies the beholder;
Let his name alone be announced to evil types,
And they would not dare henceforth to create trouble.節度押衙知司書手馬文斌

Report of local campaign. Drab paper; brusque hand.

Library holdings of various monasteries.

Rules and purposes (chiefly to be helpful to each other) of a women’s society, dating from the year959. Contributions include oil, flour, and wine. Rites mentioned are funerals and feasts. Members and officers.

msItem.title: Nidāna on ‘Intends-to-Create-Merit’ Who Is Reborn in Heaven for Having Given Her Devotion to a Stūpa

note.p: “NidānaTransformation on a Maiden in the Women’s Palace ofKing Bimbisāra[Named]‘Intends-to-Create-Merit’Who Is Reborn in Heaven for Having Given Her Devotion to a Stūpa”頻婆娑羅王后宮綵女功德意供養塔生天因緣變(head title). “Nidānaon‘Intends-to-Create-Merit’Who Is Reborn in Heaven for Having Given Her Devotion to a Stūpa”功德意供養塔生天緣(title after introduction, at T765.9). Used to make the first part of the composite text on T764–769 (ends at 767.2). Lacks identifyingpien-wenpre-verse formula except once in the concluding portion which is on; should be classed as a mixednidāna. Begins (764.2–765.5) with the same seat-settling text as that (344.3–345.7) which precedes the prosimetric narrative of the destruction of demons later on this same scroll. An important distinction, however, is that it lacks the identifyingya-tso-wenformula of the latter. In its place, it has a short prose bridge leading from the introduction (seat-settling text minus sūtra title quotation formula) to thenidānaproper. The prosimetric narrative of the destruction of demons (lacks titles at head and end) follows immediately after the first piece on v° is abandoned. Used in collation of T344.3(年)–345.5, 345.7, 346.9–354.10. After this point, the present ms — which continues with an extract from a sūtra about an Indian king — is completely different fromwhich addressed itself to topical matters. The parts of the various speakers are marked almost as though this were a playscript. All texts on v° have the same distinctive angular style of calligraphy as r° although it varies from quite small to rather large. Few corrections, additions, and erasures throughout.

Inconsistent, ill-formed, poor hand; corrections, additions, erasures. Irregularly ruled. Ruling stops at end of sections and is followed by large empty spaces which were probably originally intended for pictures. The sequence is thus prose, verse, blank spaces; prose, verse, blank space; and so on. The beginning of each section is marked in the top margin by a circle. First fully visible characters are at T732.10.3; first section, consisting of 46 lines of writing and 5 unfilled lines, ends at 737.1 and is followed by a space 38¼” long. The second section, consisting of 10 lines of writing and one unfilled line, begins at 737.2, ends at 738.2, and is followed by 9⅞” of space. The third section, consisting of 11 lines, begins at 738.3, ends at 739.7.9, and is followed by a space that is 11⅞” in length. The fourth section, consisting of 16 filled and 6 unfilled lines, begins at 739.9, ends at 741.5, and is followed by 4⅕” of space. The fifth section, consisting of 19 lines of writing and 3 empty lines, begins at 741.6, ends at 743.5, and is followed by 5⅞” of empty space. The sixth section, consisting of 9 lines of writing, begins at 743.6, ends at 743.12, and is followed by 5⅛” of empty space. The seventh and last section, consisting of 18 lines of writing, begins at 743.13, ends at 744.12, and is followed by the title in one line (see below), two empty lines, and 7⅛” of space. Colophon (in same hand as the main text):“Onthe fifth day of the intercalary sixth month in the second,ting-ch’ou, year of the Peace and Prosperity reign period[i.e.,August 22, 977], the lay scholarYang Yüan-shouof theManifest Virtue Temple, having pondered the matter by himself, made a vow to create blessings by writing in full thisTransformation onMaudgalyāyanain one scroll. It is his determination that, in the future, together withŚākyamuni Buddha, he shall be reborn a Buddha once he encountersMaitreya. If, later, there are individuals who, expressing a similar faith, write out in full theTransformation onMaudgalyāyanaand similarly maintain the power of their vow, they will avoid falling upon the three paths of hell.”太平興國二年歲在丁㺭(=丒)潤(→閏)六月五日顯德寺學仕郎楊[#191](=願)受一人思[#192] //發願㑅(=作)福[#193][#194]此目連變一卷後同釋迦[#195]尼佛壹會弥勒生作仏//為[#196](=定) 後有衆生同發信心[#197]盡目連變者同池(→持)[#198]力莫墮三途. Prosimetric vernacular narrative aboutMaudgalyāyana’s search for his mother in hell (no title). T756–759. Rather dark beige paper. Large, fairly good hand; few corrections. Not a transformation text. First pre-verse formula is of the type“about that time, what may be said?”當尔(=爾)之時有何言語. The other verse portions are not preceded by any particular identifying formula. The third section of verse is preceded by“Thereupon he leapt into the sky and went before his father whom he asked where his mother had gone.”遂即騰身天上到於父前借問孃孃趣向甚處. The fourth section is preceded by“I hope that you do not begrudge your emotions and tell me where mother was reborn.”願父莫惜情懷說母所生之處. In spite of the fact that these sentences end in“place”處, in no way do they constitute the transformation text pre-verse formula because the word here has its literal meaning and does not signify narrative locus. At very beginning refers to an introduction that is lacking on this copy:上來所說序分竟自下第二正宗者.Maudgalyāyana’s mother is here referred to as靖提instead of the usual青提. Stops copying at T759.11 before text is finished, then jumps ahead to append the section beginning at 759.12 here but which ought to come much later in the story. Again, he stops copying without finishing.

The only other writing on v° is two practice characters.

On February 9, 1982, I learned of the existence of at least one additional copy of thetransformation onWang Ling王陵. It is owned by a private collector inChina(whose name I am not liberty to divulge) and has not previously been noticed (cf. T47) in any account of Tun-huang materials. The collector informed me that he purchased the ms before the Cultural Revolution at theCultural Relics Store文物商店inPeking. He described it to me as being a booklet of three or four pages of light beige paper. This accords well with other know transformations onWang Ling(inventory items 147, 367, and 590). The collector told me that, when he was examining Tun-huang mss at theCultural Relics Store, he saw one or two other copies similar to his but he could not buy them because the prices were very high. After the Cultural Revolution, cultural relics were no longer sold to private citizens and it is not clear what became of theTun-huangmss at theCultural Relic Store. Perhaps these are the “one thousand or so uncatalogued mss” in the basement of thePeking National Librarythat came into the hands of the Chinese authorities “since the Revolution.” But I know for a fact that many private collectors inChinasecretly retain Tun-huang mss that came into their possession both before and after the Revolution. The history of the discovery and dispersal of theTun-huangcave library shows that there was ample opportunity for many of the mss to be sold or pilfered even beforeStein,Pelliot,Ol’denburg,Otani, and the Ch’ing government carted off the major portions. I suspect now that there may be as many as one or two thousand mss not yet accounted for. Among these, there is likely to be about a dozen items that include popular literary texts. I am delighted to have located one of them, but it is ironic (after my round-the-world trip) that I did so inPhiladelphia. As soon as the owner can make photographs of the ms available to me, I will publish it in an appropriate journal.
